ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a robust understanding of Professor Ackerman's new theoretical framework for understanding and analyzing constitutional history. I also gained knowledge on the history of 20th century constitutions and their evolution, and developed a topic for my master's thesis. s
The skill to analyze constitutional developments from a historical perspective

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course worked well as a seminar, however, some additional reading in addition to Ackerman's text might have been helpful for developing a more robust conversation and debate. Professor Ackerman welcomed critiques of his theory, and his responses, whether to written submissions or in class contributions, were unflinching in dissecting their logical and substantial merit.
Strengths: originality of the class, discusssing with one of the leading scholars in the field

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, Professor Ackerman is a dynamic and innovative thinker, who encourages his students to pursue research and other opportunities.
I all depends on the interest of other students, but in general I would recommend this class
